channel.title: Perl Weekly #523
channel.description: Hand-picked news and articles about Perl - Made with love by TabHub(https://tabhub.io)

item.title: The Funhouse Mirror of Perl Criticism
item.description: An excellent article about the tools you can use to improve the way you and your team writes Perl code. However, how can you make sure you don't break your code while you implement the changes recommended by these tools?
item.author: mark_gardner

item.title: Zapp: Runbook Automation
item.description: I did not know what a runbook is, I guess it is something others call a checklist. What I do know is that I agree about the problems with Jenkins and I'd love to see something like this being developed. It can be an excellent tool for SREs and people whom are often called DevOps engineers. IMHO, in order to make it catch on it needs its own web-site that is not MetaCPAN. It needs to have an installation that does not require any knowledge of Perl. These are two big areas where others could help the project. Of course 'just' using it and reporting any issues would also be extremely valuable.
item.author: doug_bell

item.title: perlbrew improved
item.description: perlbrew to better name each build that is based on an arbitrary commit and not on a released version of Perl.
item.author: david_cantrell

item.title: Speaking at Developer Career Day 2021
item.description: Many people complain how perl has a bad reputation based on incorrect information outside of the Perl bubble. Very few do anything about it anything. Try blogging outside the bubble.
item.author: mark_gardner

item.title: Perl UV binding hits version 2.000
item.description: libuv is a cross-platform event handling library, which focuses on providing nicely portable abstractions for things like TCP sockets, timers, and sub-process management between UNIX, Windows and other platforms. UV is the Perl bindings for it.
item.author: paul_evans

item.title: Are you using Cache::Memcached and its ->stats method?
item.description: A module that is probably used by some large projects, but not maintained any more. Without a link to its public VCS, if it even has a public VCS. Probably the best approach would be to reach out to the original author and the author of the most recent release via their email or social network profiles.
item.author: lee_johnson

item.title: Release 1.56 of perl-workflow, a bug fix release

item.title: How deep is a recursion in Perl?
